explanation:
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — This macro is used to obtain the impl pointer (impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(...,*token)). The macro could expand to code that performs string operations (e.g. name lookups, copies, or formatting). Inspecting it is required to ensure no <string.h> functions (strcpy/strncpy/strlen/memcpy/etc.) are invoked with pointers that could be out-of-bounds.

OS_impl_filehandle_table — The object table being indexed by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET. Its definition (initializers, accessor helpers, or operator overloads/macros) could contain string handling (e.g. copying stored path/name fields) that must be checked for out-of-bounds accesses.

OS_impl_file_internal_record_t — The type of impl. Knowing its fields (fd, selectable, and any other members) is required to see whether accessing or assigning impl->fd/selectable triggers any hidden string operations (constructors, helpers, or implicit calls) that could call <string.h> functions.

OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — This function is listed as a callee (likely used by the object-table macro). Its implementation must be inspected because it may perform name-to-index translation or token handling that could call string.h functions (strlen/strcpy/memcpy/etc.) on token contents or internal strings.

OS_DEBUG — The debug logging macro/function is used with format string and local_path/strerror outputs. Its expansion/implementation may call string handling functions (e.g. snprintf, vsnprintf wrappers, intermediate buffer copies, or helpers that use memcpy/strcat/strcpy). Inspecting it ensures those uses do not invoke out-of-bounds accesses on local_path or returned strings.

strerror — Called inside the OS_DEBUG invocation. Although strerror usually returns a pointer to a static message, its implementation may call string handling functions or return a pointer into an internal buffer; include it to confirm no string.h functions are invoked on user-provided buffers and that the returned pointer use is safe.

env errno — The global errno identifier is passed to strerror; include it to confirm correct usage and rule out any custom errno-like wrapper that might interact with string handling functions.

open — The POSIX open(local_path, ...) call reads the pathname string; while open itself is not a <string.h> API, implementations may internally use string functions. Include open to confirm no hidden usage of <string.h> functions leads to out-of-bounds accesses of local_path, and to ensure local_path is used only as input (not copied by string.h functions) within this call.

Note: The goal is to identify any callees/macros/objects reachable from OS_FileOpen_Impl that might invoke standard string.h functions (strlen/strcpy/memcpy/etc.) or perform string copying/manipulation with the pointers local_path or other related buffers. The listed symbols are the minimal set to inspect for potential violations of the MISRA rule in this function.
